entry.title: Three analytics problem
entry.content:
User accusation can be hard, especially if youâ€™re in a small team or if youâ€™re on your own. Often you find yourself worrying why you are not getting enough users. Why users are churning your app. Gathering information about users and their behaviors can be a good starting point, but there is no guarantee that with more data you can address the challenges more appropriately.

This often introduces dilemmas and complexities, especially in management, data analysis, and growth aspects of your team regarding the strategies should be taken to gather these information. On the development side, the complexities can also be intense; Working with third-parties analytics platforms, each with their own convections, rapid changes in the tools and dependencies that being used and sometimes you want to combine multiple analytics tools to achieve your goals. The question becomes: How you can develop a resilient code that can more easily tolerate these changes?

I had to develop a multi-platform analytics system with three dependencies at work a while ago, and I developed a simple solution that I believe can be a good starting point for handling these cases.

Analytics system that works with multiple platforms

Okay, letâ€™s say for an action that the user takes in your app you need to send several events to multiple platforms. Assuming you have a really rational base code, something like this

func purchaseButtonTapped() {
  //some relevant action for purchasing
}

And unfortunately it will turn into

func purchaseButtonTapped() {
  //some relevant action for purchasing
 
  //send and event to the platform A which requires an id:     string and a value: [string: Any]

  //send and event to the platform B which requires an id: string and a value: string

  //send and event to the platform C that has its own event object like;
  //let event = System3Event()
  //event.data = [purchaseID: Price]
}

This can immediately make the code unreadable and introduce many unrelated logics. Since all of these platforms have their own convections, Itâ€™s possible to end up with event handling code thatâ€™s twice as much as your logic code. And what if suddenly youâ€™re told to change one analytics platform to another with different convections. Itâ€™s pretty much obvious that you need to move this code somewhere else, plus, you need some abstractions there to handle all of these pervasive code.

Defining events

Letâ€™s start defining a protocol for all of our events

protocol ReportableEvent {}

And as an example letâ€™s define a purchase and signup event and conform them to ReportableEvent. Note that there would be no analytics platform convention here.

struct SignUpEvent: ReportableEvent {
  enum AuthenticationPlatform {
    //...
  }
  let userID: String
  let authenticationPlatform: AuthenticationPlatform
}

struct PurchaseEvent: ReportableEvent {
  let userID: String
  let price: Double
  let discount: Double
}

Finally letâ€™s define an event handler that accepts and handles all these events under ReportableEvent type. The main job of it is to encapsulate all of those analytics platformsâ€™ codes and prevent it from spreading throughout our code.

import AnalyticsPlatformA
import AnalyticsPlatformB
//... more analytics systems

struct EventHandler {
  let analyticsPlatformA: AnalyticsPlatformA
  let analyticsPlatformB: AnalyticsPlatformB
  //....
  
  func setup() {
    //here you set up analytics platforms dependencies
  }
  
  func handleEvent(some ReportableEvent) {
    // two main tasks here
    // create each analytics platform specific data
    // call analytics platform functions  
    // ðŸ”´ seems a bit problematic, isn't it?
  }
}

Platforms dedicated events

Well, currently there are two problems with our event handling system.

1) Events can have their own specific data, and the question is whether we should map that data to analytics platformsâ€™ data in the handleEvent method?

2) Sometimes we only want to send certain events to the specific platforms. For example purchasing should be sent to analytics platform A and B but sign up event only needs to be sent to platformA.

While itâ€™s possible to write if else statements with gigantic conditions that checks the all the possible events and decide their corresponding platform and required data, it is pretty obvious that it canâ€™t be scaled.

Additionally, one other criteria for our event system is to keep the analytics platforms-related code in its own domain and separated from the definition of events.

With the above conditions in mind letâ€™s define the platform compatibilities as protocols like;

protocol EventForAnalyticsPlatformA: ReportableEvent {
  var platformAData: (id: String, value: [String: Any]) { get }
}

protocol EventForAnalyticsPlatformB: ReportableEvent {
  var platformBData: (id: String, value: Int) { get }
}

And then extend our event definitions to conform to their corresponding platformsâ€™ requirements;

//we want to send SignUpEvent to AnalyticsPlatformA and AnalyticsPlatformB
extension SignUpEvent: EventForAnalyticsPlatformA {
  var platformAData (id: String, value: [String: Any]) {
    //...
  }
}

extension SignUpEvent: EventForAnalyticsPlatformB {
  var platformBData: (id: String, value: Int) {
    //...
  }
}

//we want to send purchase event only to AnalyticsPlatformB
struct PurchaseEvent: EventForAnalyticsPlatformB {
  var platformBData: (id: String, value: Int) {
    //...
  }
}

As a result the handleEvent method of our event handler is going to have a simple implementation like;

//let's assume our dependencies handle their events like
class AnalyticsPlatformA {
  func handleEventWith(id: String, value: [String: Any]) { //... }
}
class AnalyticsPlatformA {
  func event(id: String, value: Int) { //... }
}

//then the `handleEvent` of our event handler going to be like
struct EventHandler {
//...
func handleEvent(some ReportableEvent) {
  switch event {
    case let event as EventForAnalyticsPlatformA:
      analyticsPlatformA.handleEventWith(id: event.id, value: event.value)
    case let event as EventForAnalyticsPlatformB:
      analyticsPlatformB.event(id: event.id, value: event.value)
    default:
      break
    }
  }
}

Ultimately we end up with this nice modular structure

-main application
  --events definations
    ---purchase event
    ---signup event
    ---...
-events handler
  --event handler
    --events +
      --purchase event + platformA
      --signup event + platformBA
      --signup event + platformB
    --dependencies

Note that right now we can easily put the event handler, the platform-related code of the events, and all the analytics third-party dependencies into its own package if we want to follow a more modular practices in our code.

Conclusion

Well, I hope this way of encapsulating analytics-related code can make working with our main code much easier and make our Data analysis colleagues happy. As always you can find me on Github and LinkedIn.

Thanks for reading, Cheers!

entry.title: Use Combine to implement a Github OAuth authenticator

link.title: Use Combine to implement a Github OAuth authenticator

entry.content:
Itâ€™s been a couple of years since the introduction of async await in Swift and the debates between usage of Swiftâ€™s modern concurrency and combine to address asynchronous requirements have become quite controversial. While using async await is usually more readable and understandable, especially for developers with no prior experience in reactive programming (Canâ€™t truly say I have). However sometimes combine truly shines, particularly when it comes to introducing understandable pipelines in your app.

Recently I had to implement a GitHub authenticator for a small utility tool and, I found that some features of the Combine were perfectly suitable for it. First letâ€™s take a quick review of how Github Oath authentication works.

Github Oath

You can find the detailed descriptions in the official docs. However for my usage I needed to use the solution that is explained in this section.

Basically, you have to follow these steps;

1) Create an app in your Github account and enable the OAuth authentication for it. After that, copy the client ID that it will provide for you.

2) Use the client ID to send a POST request to this URL https://github.com/login/device/code for receiving auser_code

3) Show a web page with this URL to the user, or prompt the user to open the URL. After that show them the user_code and ask them to enter it on that page.

4) Since you donâ€™t have any clue that the user has entered the code or not you need to frequently call the API with this URL https://github.com/login/oauth/access_token to check the status.

5) Once you receive a result from the latter API, you can stop the polling and handle the result based on whether it contains an error or the token that youâ€™re looking for.

Implementing it in our app

Starting the authentication process

First, since we have some sort of state management associated with this authentication process, letâ€™s define a class called GithubOAuth, like this;

final class GithubOAuth {
  let session = URLSession.shared
  private let clientID = "<YOUR_CLIENT_ID>"
  private var redirectInfo: RedirectInfo?
}

RedirectInfo is a model that represents the response that you get in the first API call.

struct RedirectInfo {
  let expiresIn: Int
  let interval: Int
  let code: String
  let deviceCode: String
}

Note: You need to pars it from a query string. You can create an empty URLComponent, pass the query string as components.query and read its items by components.queryItems. Alternatively you can pars it manually. Iâ€™ve implemented a simple manual parsing function in the final sample code that you can use.

Now you can write the start of your authentication process.

final class GithubOAuth {
func startAuth() async throws -> (redirectURL: URL, code: String) {
  var request = URLRequest(url: URL(string: "https://github.com/login/device/code")!)
  request.httpMethod = "POST"
  request.url?.append(queryItems: [URLQueryItem(name: "client_id", value: clientID)])
  let (data, res) = try await session.data(for: request)
  let string = String(data: data, encoding: .utf8)!
  redirectInfo = RedirectInfo(string: string)
  return (
    URL(string: "https://github.com/login/device")!,
    redirectInfo!.code
  )
}
}

After we ask the user to enter the code at the redirectURL now itâ€™s time to poll the second API and check if the user has entered the code or not. Here is the place that Combine comes in!

Polling the authentication state API

Letâ€™s start by defining a function that will produce our polling states over time.

final class GithubOAuth {
//...
private func pollAuthenticationStatusPublisher(
  clientID: String,
  deviceCode: String,
  interval: Int
) -> AnyPublisher<GithubAuthState, GithubOAuthError> {
}
}

The GithubPollResponse is the response of polling api. It indicates that whether polling should be continued, if it has failed or if the token has been received.

struct GithubPollResponse {
  let token: String?
  let continuePolling: Bool
  let error: String?
}

The same parsing mechanism thatâ€™s been mentioned for RedirectInfo can be used for constructing GithubPollResponse from a query string. For better readability we can map this to an GithubAuthState enum and get rid of unnecessary combinations of the three optional properties.

enum GithubAuthState {
  case keep
  case finished(GithubToken)
}

extension GithubPollResponse {
  func toAuthState() throws -> GithubAuthState {
    if let error { 
      throw PollError(message: error)
    }
    if !continuePolling && token == nil {
      throw PollError(message: "Token should be provided with a successful result") 
    }
    if continuePolling {
      return .keep 
    }
    return .finished(GithubToken(accessToken: token!))
  }

  struct PollError: Error {
    let message: String
  }
}

Create the polling pipeline

We need to perform the polling periodically based on the time interval that we received from the first API. First letâ€™s create a timer.

Timer
.publish(every: TimeInterval(interval + 1), on: .main, in: .default)
.autoconnect()
//continued ...

With every event that the timer publishes we want to poll the second API. Since weâ€™re already using Combine to create a timer, it would be the best to create poll requests also as Combine publishers. Whenever we are in this situation of creating bunch of publisher with events of another publisher, the `flatMap` operator can be quite useful in order to flatten all of them into one upstream publisher.

//... After the timer
.flatMap(maxPublishers: .max(15)) { [unowned self] _ in
  self.pollAuthenticationDataTaskPublisher(clientID, deviceCode)
}
//continued ...

//Somewhere else in our class
extension GithubOAuth {
  typealias PollAuthenticationDataTaskPublisher = (
    _ clientID: String,
    _ deviceCode: String
  ) -> AnyPublisher<URLSession.DataTaskPublisher.Output, URLSession.DataTaskPublisher.Failure>
  
  fileprivate static func _pollAuthenticationDataTaskPublisher(
    clientID: String,
    deviceCode: String
  ) -> AnyPublisher<URLSession.DataTaskPublisher.Output, URLSession.DataTaskPublisher.Failure> {
    var request = URLRequest(url: URL(string: "https://github.com/login/oauth/access_token")!)
    request.httpMethod = "POST"
    request.url?.append(queryItems: [
      URLQueryItem(name: "client_id", value: clientID),
      URLQueryItem(name: "device_code", value: deviceCode),
      URLQueryItem(name: "grant_type", value: "urn:ietf:params:oauth:grant-type:device_code")
    ])
    return URLSession.shared.dataTaskPublisher(for: request).eraseToAnyPublisher()
  }
}

PollAuthenticationDataTaskPublisher accepts required parameters and provides necessary elements for polling the API and returns a publisher that performs an asynchronous networking code with combine.

Another nice thing is that with maxPublisher, we can define maximum amount of ongoing api calls and fail the publisher if the result canâ€™t be received after certain amount of API calls. After that, we add bunch of error mapping and result mapping to read and convert the response of the API.

//...
.mapError(GithubOAuthError.pollAPIError)
.tryMap{ arg throws -> String in
  guard let string = String(data: arg.data, encoding: .utf8) else {
    throw GithubOAuthError.invalidData
  }
  return string
}
.tryMap {
  let response = GithubPollResponse(string: $0)
  return try response.toAuthState()
}
.mapError(GithubOAuthError.authStateError)

//..continued

And at the end as always we need to simplify our gigantic(!) publisher type with;

//...
.eraseToAnyPublisher()

Observe the polling results

For the users of our Github authenticator, itâ€™s really not that important to know the polling states and its implementation details. In addition to that, itâ€™s also required to cancel the polling process when an error occurs or the token is received. Also, I personally often try to convert Combine publishers to their async await equivalent if itâ€™s possible. With all that in mind, letâ€™s write a function that will use our polling pipeline to retrieve user credentials.

final class GithubOAuth {
  //...
  func observeAuthentication() async throws -> GithubToken {
    guard let redirectInfo else {
      throw GithubAuthenticatorError.authPollDidNotRespond
    }
    let publisher = pollAuthenticationStatusPublisher(
      clientID: clientID,
      deviceCode: redirectInfo.deviceCode,
      interval: redirectInfo.interval
    )
    
    for try await values in publisher.values {
      switch values {
        case .keep:
          continue
        case .finished(let token):
          return token
      }
    }
    throw GithubAuthenticatorError.authPollDidNotRespond
  }
}

Using our Github authenticator

Now we can use our authenticator in other places of the project. One example of it can be like this;

struct GithubOAuthView: View {
  let oAuth = GithubOAuth()
  var body: some View {
    //....
    Button("Login") {
      Task {
        do {
          let (url, code) = try await oAuth.startAuth()
          open(url: url)
          self.code = code
          let token = try await oAuth.observeAuthentication()
          self.token = token.accessToken
        } catch {
          //handle the errors gracefully
        }
      }
    }
  }
}

Conclusion

In this article, with a practical example, I have explained how we can still benefit from some powerful features of the Combine framework like Timer and flatMap. Arguably, itâ€™s still possible to implement these functionalities with other tools, but as weâ€™ve seen here, sometimes Combine can be the easiest and the most convenient approach. The complete code of the Github authenticator is available on Gist.

As always if you have any suggestions or questions you can reach out to me at my Github or LinkedIn.

Hope you find this one useful.

Cheers!

entry.title: Setting up Core Data in a package

link.title: Setting up Core Data in a package

entry.content:
There are couple of issues that Iâ€™ve encountered recently when I wanted to move all my CoreData logics from the main application to a separate packages. I couldnâ€™t find any specific place that addressed all of these problems. Most of the solutions and workarounds that I found were buried in the stack overflow answers or Apple developer forums discussions. So here I gather three major problems that are quite common to face.

Setting up Persistent Container

In your packages, you should manually setup the CoreData persistent container. In order to do this, you need a path to your Data Model file. For the applications, we tend to use

Bundle.main.url(forResource: "Your-DataModel-File-Name", withExtension: "momd")

But when youâ€™re in a package, you should use module bundle instead of main like:

Bundle.module.url(forResource: "Your-DataModel-File-Name", withExtension: "momd")

After that, you need to move your Data Model files into a specific directory called Resources. If you donâ€™t have such a directory, create one in this hierarchical format:

<YourPackageName>
	Sources
		<YourPackageName>
			Resources

More information about packages resource management can be found at: Building resource with a Swift package. If everything goes correctly, you should be able to instantiate your Persistent Container like this:

guard let url = Bundle.module.url(forResource: "Your-DataModel-File-Name", withExtension: "momd"),
let model = NSManagedObjectModel(contentsOf: url) else {
  fatalError("Unable to load data model file")
}
PersistentContainer(name: "Your-DataModel-File-Name", managedObjectModel: model)

Creating CoreData Model Objects problem

Well, I was creating my core data object the same way I used to in apps but I faced runtime crashes and got errors like this:

let object = MyObject(context: container.viewContext)
//Error!: An NSManagedObject of class 'ModularAppKit.ArticleMO' must have a valid NSEntityDescription.

Which honestly, the error description wasnâ€™t exactly pointing out what the actual cause of the error was. So I initialized my object in this way

let entityDescription = NSEntityDescription.entity(forEntityName: "Your Entity", in: managedObjectContext)  
let object = MyObject(entity: entityDescription!, insertInto: managedObjectContext)

Everything went back to normal, and it seemed that manually adding NSEntityDescription fixed the issue. However, the actual reason of this problem was something more general, so another error appeared in a more bizarre format later on when I attempted to fetch data.

Problem with â€œFetch requestâ€ing stuff

I had this run time error that caused the application to crash when I wanted to query a bunch of objects with a simple fetch request. The error description this time was TOTALLY misleading; it was complaining that my Core Data objects donâ€™t have the correct type and they are NSManagedObjects (???)

**NSArray element failed to match the Swift Array Element type**
**Expected MyObject but found NSManagedObject**

// MyObject is the name of my Entity class

After going through a lots of hassles, it turned out the solution for this one was to go to your Core data Model Editor, in the right Xcode right panel, under entity class section, explicitly write your package name inside the model field instead of â€œCurrent Product Moduleâ€ which is the default value!

Here the module name is set to ArticlesKit, which is the name of the package.

Changing this field also fix the previous problem related to NSManagedObject creation. You no longer required to specify the entity description.

Conclusion

Well, thatâ€™s it for now. Currently, everything is working fine. If I encounter another tricky issue I will update this post. In retrospective, I think it was worth all the hassles. Moving all of my Core Data logic into my CRUD package feels so nice right now, and as a result, my main app is capable of working with any form of local database, which is really cool!

If you have any questions, similar experiences or faced another issue when setting up your Core Data inside a package, feel free to reach out to me at my Github or LinkedIn. I would be happy to discuss.

Thanks For reading! Cheers!

entry.title: Testing Observable Objects
entry.content:
Itâ€™s usually a good practice to put view logics into ObservableObjects when working with SwiftUI. It brings various benefits like; reusability, testability, avoid SwiftUI view cycles and more. One common scenario that we may find ourselves in, is retrieving data and handling its view side effects. Itâ€™s also common that our data retrievals to be asynchronous, as shown in the example below:

struct Item {
  let name: String
}

class ItemList: ObservableObject {
  @Published var items: [Item] = []
  private let loadItems: () async -> [Item]

  init(loadItems: @escaping () async -> [Item]) {
    self.loadItems = loadItems
  }

  func load() {
    Task {
      let items = await loadItems()
      self.items = items
    }
  }
}

As you can see we used function injection let loadItems: () async -> [Item] to enable injecting different item loading mechanisms into our ItemList. In production code, we may use networking or data base functions to return items. For testing purposes, we can simply inject a function that returns mock data, like:

func load2MockItems() -> [Item] {
  loadCallTimes += 1
  return [Item(name: "hello"), Item(name: "world")]
}

Writing Tests

Now that our ItemList is ready to test, letâ€™s write a simple test to verify that when we load items successfully, our items property will be assigned correctly.

final class ItemListTests: XCTest {
  var itemList: ItemList!
  var itemLoader: MockItemLoader!
  override func setUpWithError() throws {
    try super.setUpWithError()
    itemLoader = MockItemLoader()
    itemList = ItemList(loadItems: itemLoader.load2MockItems)
  }
  
  override func tearDownWithError() throws {
    try super.tearDownWithError()
    itemLoader = nil
    itemList = nil
  }
  
  func testItemList_whenLoadItemsSuccessfully_itemsWillBeCorrectlyAssigned() {
    //when
    itemList.load()
    
    //then
    //will thay pass??
    XCTAssertEqual(itemList.items.count, 2)
    XCTAssertEqual(itemLoader.loadCallTimes, 1) 
  }
}

final class MockItemLoader {
  var loadCallTimes = 0
  func load2MockItems() -> [Item] {
    loadCallTimes += 1
    return [Item(name: "hello"), Item(name: "world")]
  }
}

Weâ€™ve defined a MockItemLoader which not only produces some mock data, but also keeps track of its loading method calls count. In our actual test we set up the loadItems function of ItemList to use synchronous data from MockItemLoader. Then, we check if the passed function is called and the returned data is assigned correctly.

The Problem

But if we run our test, itâ€™s going to fail. The main reason is that while our `MockItemLoader` loading function is synchronous, it will be called in an asynchronous environment within our `ItemList`. We start a Task in our ItemsList load() method because we canâ€™t make any assumption about whether loading is asynchronous or not. In our testing case ,while loading itself is synchronous itâ€™s still not going to be executed synchronously, so we canâ€™t check it with our XCTAsserts. At first It might seem that we can handle this problem by introducing a small amount of delay using Task.sleep(). However itâ€™s usually a good practice to avoid any explicit latency when writing tests. On the other hand, we can utilize the onChange function of ObservableObjectâ€™s to wait for our desired behavior to appear before continuing our test.

A General solution

Since the issue that we encountered can happen for other ObservableObjects as well, letâ€™s write a general solution in form of a test private extension that can be used for all our ObservableObjectss.

extension XCTestCase {
  func wait<Object: ObservableObject>(
    forObject object: Object,
    timeout: Double,
    toChange change: (Object) -> Bool,
    testName: String = #function,
    in file: StaticString = #file,
    at line: UInt = #line
  ) async {
    let publisher = object
      .objectWillChange
      .timeout(.seconds(timeout), scheduler: DispatchQueue.main)

    for await _ in publisher.values {
      if change(object) { return }
    }
    XCTFail("Timeout Reached", file: file, line: line)
  }
}

Now we can refactor our recent test into

func testItemList_whenLoadItemsSuccessfully_itemsWillBeCorrectlyAssigned() {
  //when
  itemList.load()
  await wait(forObject: itemList, timeout: 1) { itemList in
    !itemList.items.isEmpty
  }
  //then
  XCTAssertEqual(itemList.items.count, 2)
  XCTAssertEqual(itemLoader.loadCallTimes, 1)
}

We can now see that our test will pass and also we have a convenient way of waiting for the ObservableObjects in the other tests. Hope you find this one useful! If you have any questions or workaround related to this problem feel free to reach out to me on my Github or LinkedIn.

Thanks for reading! Cheers!

entry.title: Download Manager - Part 4 - Thread safety
entry.content:
For building a modern DownloadManager so far weâ€™ve taken a look at

  • part1: URLSession and Swift modern concurrency
  • part2: Pausing and resuming download tasks
  • part3: Background downloads

In this article I explain how we can improve our DownloadManager to be safely used across different threads. In other words, make it thread-safe.

What is the issue with the current DownloadManager?

First, letâ€™s have a high-level view of how DownloadManager handles its states:

class DownloadManager: NSObject, URLSessionDownloadDelegate {
//...other properties

//state of downloads
 private var downloads: [DownloadTaskID: DownloadTask] =[:]
 private var resumeData: [DownloadTaskID: Data] = [:]

//we mutate the state from all of these bellow methods! 
 func download(from url: URL) -> DownloadTask {
  // add to downloads
}

 func resume(taskWithID id: DownloadTaskID) -> DownloadTask? {
  // add to resumeData
}

 private func urlSession(_ session: URLSession, downloadTask: URLSessionDownloadTask, didFinishDownloadingTo location: URL) {
  //remove from downloadData
}

 private func urlSession(_ session: URLSession, task: URLSessionTask, didCompleteWithError error: Error?) {
  //remove from downloadData
  //add to resumData
}

Initially, It may seem nothing is wrong with our class implementation, However if we invoke our class methods from different threads, the class state on each of those threads can be different. This is called Data Race, and itâ€™s a common concurrency problem. A Data Race occurs when a shared state is read and mutated from different threads at the same time. Different classes may take different approaches to handle such race conditions, which all of them involve a way of serializing access to their state. One of the features thatâ€™s been introduced in swift modern concurrency is the actor, which is a suitable solution for a problem we currently have.

What is an actor?

The actor is a modern concurrency solution designed to prevent data races. You can learn more about actors in the Swift documentations. Apparently the only change that is required to turn a class into an actor is replace the class keyword to actor.

Well it simply just â€¦ not works! at least in our case. Although actors are reference types like classes but they have two main differences.

  • Actors serialize all access to their method and properties, which is the primary reason we are considering them now.
  • Actors donâ€™t support subclassing, because well, they are not actually classes!

The main reason we inherited our Downloadmanager from NSObject was enable it to conform to URLSessionDownloadDelegate which allows us to track the progress and results of our downloads. Well, can we export these URLSessionDownloadDelegate responsibilities to another object, specially now that our DownloadManager implementation is becoming quite massive?

Modernizing URLSessionDownloadDelegate with an Adapter

letâ€™s create an adapter that conforms to URLSessionDownloadDelegate and provides a nicer functional interface for working with the needed delegate methods.

class DownloadDelegateAdaptor: NSObject, URLSessionDownloadDelegate {
 struct Config {
  var fileFinishedDownloading: (_ session: URLSession, _ downloadTask: URLSessionDownloadTask,_ location: URL) -> Void
  
  var fileDownloadingProgress: (_ session: URLSession,_ downloadTask: URLSessionDownloadTask,_ bytesWritten: Int64,_ totalBytesWritten: Int64,_ totalBytesExpectedToWrite: Int64) -> Void
  
  var didCompleteWithError: (_ session: URLSession,_ task: URLSessionTask,_ error: Error?) -> Void
  
  var backgroundSessionDidFinishEvents: (_ session: URLSession) -> Void
 }
 
 var config: Config?

 func urlSession(_ session: URLSession, downloadTask: URLSessionDownloadTask, didFinishDownloadingTo location: URL) {
  config?.fileFinishedDownloading(session,downloadTask,location)
 }
 
func urlSession(_ session: URLSession, downloadTask: URLSessionDownloadTask, didWriteData bytesWritten: Int64, totalBytesWritten: Int64, totalBytesExpectedToWrite: Int64) {
  config?.fileDownloadingProgress(session, downloadTask, bytesWritten, totalBytesWritten, totalBytesExpectedToWrite)
}

 func urlSession(_ session: URLSession, task: URLSessionTask, didCompleteWithError error: Error?) {
  config?.didCompleteWithError(session, task, error)
}

 func urlSessionDidFinishEvents(forBackgroundURLSession session: URLSession) {
  config?.backgroundSessionDidFinishEvents(session)
 }
}

As you can see the adaptor doesnâ€™t do anything special. It simply passes its config functions to the corresponding method of URLSessionDownloadDelegate.Now that our adaptor can handle URLSessionDownloadDelegate, instead of passing DownloadManager to handle its URLSession delegate, letâ€™s create an instance of DownloadDelegateAdaptor and pass it as our URLSession delegate.

actor DownloadManager {
  //...
  lazy private var downloadSession: URLSession = {
    let session = URLSession(
      configuration: .default,
      delegate: downloadDelegate,
      delegateQueue: nil
    )
    return session
  }()
  
  //...
  lazy private var downloadDelegate: URLSession.DownloadDelegateAdaptor = {
    let delegate = URLSession.DownloadDelegateAdaptor()
    delegate.config = URLSession.DownloadDelegateAdaptor.Config(
      fileFinishedDownloading: urlSession(_:downloadTask:didFinishDownloadingTo:),
      fileDownloadingProgress: urlSession(_:downloadTask:didWriteData:totalBytesWritten:totalBytesExpectedToWrite:),
      didCompleteWithError: urlSession(_:task:didCompleteWithError:),
      backgroundSessionDidFinishEvents: urlSessionDidFinishEvents(forBackgroundURLSession:)
    )
    return delegate
}()

Note that we are keeping the previous URLSessionDownloadDelegate methods in our DownloadManager. We will pass them as the configuration functions to our DownloadDelegateAdaptor. Another benefit of this adaption is that we can reuse our DownloadDelegateAdaptor as a modern replacement of URLSessionDownloadDelegate in other situations where we prefer using actors or value types. The same pattern can also be applied to other URLSession delegates like URLSessionTaskDelegate and `URLSessionDataDelegate

Well that wraps up these series. I hope Iâ€™ve covered most of the challenges that I faced while building this DownloadManager. URLSession APIs have indeed been modernized and improved significantly over the past couple of years. However sometimes we still need to use old APIs and delegate patterns to achieve various tasks. Nevertheless itâ€™s worthwhile to consider different alternatives to modernize old apis, ultimately leading to interesting solutions that can be reuse elsewhere.

The complete implementation of DownloadManager is available on Gist.

Also if you have any comments or suggestions, feel free to reach out to me on my LinkedIn or Github.

Thanks for reading, Cheers!

entry.title: Download Manager - Part 3 - Background downloads
entry.content:
In the past series (part1, part2) we went through how we can build a DownloadManager that has modern concurrency-friendly apis and capable of pausing and resuming failed and canceled downloads.

In this article we will take a look at how we can add background download capability into our DownloadManager. Background download support is crucial for downloading large files. Many users may exit our app while a downloads is in progress, causing our app to enter a suspended state However users will expect the ongoing downloads to resume seamlessly. Fortunately supporting background downloads is not overly complicated, So letâ€™s see how we we can implement this feature.

Background Download Capability

The initial step in supporting background downloads is to define a dedicated URLSession with background configuration.

class DownloadManager: NSObject, URLSessionDownloadDelegate {
 //...
  lazy private var backgroundDownloadSession: URLSession = {
    let config = URLSessionConfiguration.background()
    config.isDiscretionary = false
    config.sessionSendsLaunchEvents = true
    let session = URLSession(
      configuration: config,
      delegate: downloadDelegate,
      delegateQueue: nil
    )
    return session
 }()
 
}

isDiscretionary flag should be set to true for large file downloads with lower priority so the system may schedule the download based on various device conditions. However, in our case, if the app goes into the background, we often want the ongoing download to resume as soon as possible. Therefore, itâ€™s been set to false.

Now we have to define a method that uses our background configured session to download files:

func backgroundDownload(
  from url: URL,
  earliestBeginDate: Date = Date.now,
  countOfBytesClientExpectsToReceive: Int64? = nil,
) -> DownloadTask {
  let task = backgroundDownloadSession.downloadTask(
    with: URLRequest(url: url))
  
  task.earliestBeginDate = earliestBeginDate
  if let countOfBytesClientExpectsToReceive {
    task.countOfBytesClientExpectsToReceive =
    countOfBytesClientExpectsToReceive 
  }

  let downloadTask = DownloadTask(urlSessionTask: task)
  downloads[task.taskIdentifier] = downloadTask
  task.resume()
  return downloadTask
}

This method implementation is similar to our regular download method that we implemented in part1 but with additional configurations. We capture earliestBeginDate, countOfBytesClientExpectsToReceive parameters and pass them to DownloadTask.

Handling app suspension

If our app gets suspended in the background, our background downloads may continue in another process. When theyâ€™re finished, the system resumes the app and notify that the download is finished by calling this method in the AppDelegate:

func application(
 _ application: UIApplication,
 handleEventsForBackgroundURLSession
 identifier: String,
 completionHandler: @escaping () -> Void)

We should store the completion handler in our DownloadManager and call it when this URLSessionDelegate method is being called.

func urlSessionDidFinishEvents(forBackgroundURLSession session: URLSession)

More information for handling app suspension can be found in the Apple documentations. In our use case, the changes that will be needed are:

class AppDelegate: NSObject, UIApplicationDelegate {
// ....
 func application(
  _ application: UIApplication,
  handleEventsForBackgroundURLSession identifier: String,
  completionHandler: @escaping () -> Void) {
   DownloadManager.main.backgroundCompletionHandler = completionHandler
 }
}

class DownloadManager: NSObject, URLSessionDownloadDelegate {
 //...
 var backgroundCompletionHandler: (() -> Void)?
 //...
 func urlSessionDidFinishEvents(
 forBackgroundURLSession session: URLSession) {
  backgroundCompletionHandler?()
 }
}

There are several good points related to background downloading have been mentioned in this SwiftLee blog post. Definitely worth to check them out. URLSession: Common pitfalls with background download & upload tasks

In the next article, Iâ€™m going to explain potential concurrency problems that we may face with the current implementation of DownloadManager and why itâ€™s recommended to consider our DownloadManager to be an actor.

The complete implementation of DownloadManager is available on Gist.

Thank you for reading.

Cheers!

entry.title: Download Manager - Part 2 - Pausing and resuming download tasks

link.title: Download Manager - Part 2 - Pausing and resuming download tasks

entry.content:
In the previous article I explained how I built a DownloadManager that not only capable of downloading files, but also shows their progress. I also tried to make its methods more compatible with modern concurrency. In other words, tried to keep those delegate methods that is used for tracking download progress, internally.

Itâ€™s certainly important, especially for downloading large files, to have the ability to pause and resume downloads. Additionally since downloads may fail sometimes, we should be able to check if itâ€™s possible to resume the download from the point it failed, instead of starting a completely new download from the beginning. According to the docs, when a download is canceled it may return resume data. This data can be received as a closure or as a result of async await cancellation. By storing this data, we will be able to resume the download later.

Identifying DownloadTasks

To integrate resuming data caching into the download manager, First letâ€™s pass the URLSessionTask to our DownloadTask upon its initialization.

struct DownloadTask {
  let urlSessionTask: URLSessionDownloadTask

  init(urlSessionTask: URLSessionDownloadTask) {
    self.urlSessionTask = urlSessionTask
  }
}

Note that the DownloadTask currently acts as a wrapper around the URLSessionTask. It is arguable that right now itâ€™s possible to call URLSessionTask methods directly without needing to use our DownloadManager, or in other words, our download Manager is not a complete proxy for our URLSessionTasks. Since we are only interested in task identifier and cancelation method of URLSessionTask , we can make URLSessionTask private and only expose these functionalities outside.

struct DownloadTask {
  let urlSessionTask: URLSessionDownloadTask
  var id: DownloadTaskID { urlSessionTask.taskIdentifier }
	
  init(urlSessionTask: URLSessionDownloadTask) {
    self.urlSessionTask = urlSessionTask
  }
	
  func cancel() async -> Data? {
    return await urlSessionTask.cancelByProducingResumeData()
  }
}

If weâ€™re using DownloadManager as a package, itâ€™s also better to consider cancel() as an internal method.

Updating The DownloadManager

letâ€™s add a cancel method and a dictionary that contains cancellation resume data to our DownloaodManager.

class DownloadManager: NSObject, URLSessionDownloadDelegate {
  //...
  private var resumeData: [DownloadTaskID: Data] = [:]
  //...
  func cancel(taskWithID id: DownloadTaskID) {
    guard let task = downloads[id] else { return }
    task.finish(error: DownloadCancellation())
    downloads.removeValue(forKey: id)
    Task {
      if let resumeData = await task.cancel() {
        self.resumeData[id] = resumeData
      }
    }
  }
}

As previously mentioned, resuming can also be useful for tasks that have been failed. letâ€™s check if our failed tasks have resume data, and if so, store their resume datas.

class DownloadManager: NSObject, URLSessionDownloadDelegate {
	//...
  func urlSession(_ session: URLSession, task: URLSessionTask, didCompleteWithError error: Error?) {
    guard let error else { return }
    let download = downloads[task.taskIdentifier]
    download?.finish(error: error)
    downloads.removeValue(forKey: task.taskIdentifier)
    let userInfo = (error as NSError).userInfo
    if let resumeData = 
    userInfo[NSURLSessionDownloadTaskResumeData] as? Data {
      self.resumeData[task.taskIdentifier] = resumeData
    }
  }
}

For resuming tasks we only need to find the corresponding data in our resume data dictionary and start a new URLSession task with it.

class DownloadManager: NSObject, URLSessionDownloadDelegate {
	//...
  func resume(taskWithID id: DownloadTaskID) -> DownloadTask? {
    guard let data = resumeData[id] else { return nil }
    let task = downloadSession.downloadTask(withResumeData: data)
    let downloadTask = DownloadTask(urlSessionTask: task)
    downloads[task.taskIdentifier] = downloadTask
    return downloadTask
  }
}

Thatâ€™s all there is to it.

In the next article I will explain how we can add the ability to handle background downloads. As a reminder, the complete Download manager implementation is available on Gist.

Thank you for reading, Cheers!

entry.title: Download Manager - Part 1 - URLSession and Swift modern concurrency

link.title: Download Manager - Part 1 - URLSession and Swift modern concurrency

entry.content:
Apparently URLSession used to be so difficult to work with. Many people preferred using third-party network tools like AFNetworking or Alamofire. However over the past years it has its improvements. Two of its notable improvements can be the Combine and async await equivalent APIs. They replace the closure based APIs which can become error prone in advance usages. After all, nobody wants to deal with those nested closures inside each others. Despite the improvements, I faced a few challenges while building a download manager class with a modern async await APIs in mind. Initially, I came up with something like this:

struct DownloadManager {
  let downloadSession = URLSession.shared

  func download(from url: URL) async throws -> URL {
    let (url, _) = try downloadSession.download(for: URLRequest(url: url))
    return url
  }
}

This is totally fine for simple use cases, But most of the times specially for big files we want to track the download progress. Either for our logging and diagnostics or displaying the progress to the user.

Getting the download progress

Of course I had to use delegates. sigh. This URLSessionDownloadDelegate method

func urlSession(_ session: URLSession, downloadTask: URLSessionDownloadTask, didWriteData bytesWritten: Int64, totalBytesWritten: Int64, totalBytesExpectedToWrite: Int64)

Consequently, I changed my download manager from a struct to a class because It needed to inherit from NSObject to be able to conform to URLSessionDownloadDelegate. Additionally I assigned the DownloadManager class as my download session delegate.

class DownloadManager: NSObject, URLSessionDownloadDelegate {
  lazy private var downloadSession: URLSession = {
    let session = URLSession(
      configuration: .default,
      delegate: downloadDelegate,
      delegateQueue: nil
    )
    return session
	}()

	//...

	func urlSession(_ session: URLSession, downloadTask: URLSessionDownloadTask, didWriteData bytesWritten: Int64, totalBytesWritten: Int64, totalBytesExpectedToWrite: Int64) {
	//progress can be found here!
	}
}

Also, note that when you assign a delegate to your URLSession configuration, all the completion handlers of your data tasks no longer work. You have to use downloadTask(with: URLRequest(url: url)) in order to track the download progress. This unfortunately also means that you have to find if the download was successful or not within those delegate methods.

class DownloadManager: NSObject, URLSessionDownloadDelegate {
	// ....
	
  func download(from url: URL) {
    // this won't report the progress 
    let (url, _) = try downloadSession.download(
    for: URLRequest(url: url))
    // instead have to use this
    downloadSession.downloadTask(with: URLRequest(url: url))
    // this function is not async anymore
    // i can't simply return the downloaded url from here
    // :(
  }

  func urlSession(_ session: URLSession, downloadTask: URLSessionDownloadTask, didFinishDownloadingTo location: URL) {
    //figure out the download location belongs to which download task
    //by probably checking the task id?
  }

  func urlSession(_ session: URLSession, task: URLSessionTask, didCompleteWithError error: Error?) {
    //same id checking for figuring out download errors
  }
}

Well that certainly bring back bitter nostalgia and instantly throw me out of our beautiful async await world. Our beloved func download(from url: URL) async throws -> URL pure function is gone. So how do I report the downloading progress to the others? By defining my own custom delegates? Wouldnâ€™t it be nice to return an iteration that others can listen to and receive the progress update events asynchronously?

async await Adaptor

Well, asynchronous iteration! This is certeinly a use case for AsyncStream but sometimes we may only be interested in the final download result. So I decided to define a specific type for my download operation and return that back.

struct DownloadTask {
  private let progressSubjects = CurrentValueSubject<Double, Never>(0)
  private let resultsSubjects = PassthroughSubject<URL, Error>()

  var progressPublisher: AsyncThrowingPublisher<AnyPublisher<Double, Never>> {
    progressSubjects.eraseToAnyPublisher().values
  }
	
  func result() async throws -> URL? {
    for try await result in resultsSubjects.values {
      return result
    }
    preconditionFailure("Should finish with at least one value")
  }
}

I identified each download task with an ID and stored download tasks with their ids in a dictionary within my DownloadManager. For progress changes or download completions and failures I search for the corresponding download task in this dictionary and update it it to reflect those changes.

typealias DownloadTaskID = Int

class DownloadManager: NSObject, URLSessionDownloadDelegate {
  private var downloads: [DownloadTaskID: DownloadTask] = [:]
	
  func download(from url: URL) -> DownloadTask {
    //create a download task and store it and then start the task
    let task = downloadSession.downloadTask(with: URLRequest(url: url))
    downloads[task.taskIdentifier] = DownloadTask()
    task.resume()
    return downloadTask
  }
}

I used Combine subjects for progress and completion handlers, along with some helper methods for sending the correct events to those subjects.

extension DownloadTask {
  func finish(url: URL) {
    progressSubjects.send(completion: .finished)
    resultsSubjects.send(url)
    resultsSubjects.send(completion: .finished)
  }

  func finish(error: Error) {
    progressSubjects.send(completion: .finished)
    resultsSubjects.send(completion: .failure(error))
  }

  func setProgress(_ progress: Double) {
    progressSubjects.send(progress)
  }
}

Note that I didnâ€™t expose any combine APIs externally, so the users of our class donâ€™t have to import it. This makes it easier to use our code across multiple codebases.

Here is the implementation of our DownloadManager so far

class DownloadManager: NSObject, URLSessionDownloadDelegate {
  private var downloads: [DownloadTaskID: DownloadTask] = [:]
	
  func download(from url: URL) -> DownloadTask {
    let task = downloadSession.downloadTask(
		with: URLRequest(url: url))
    downloads[task.taskIdentifier] = DownloadTask()
    task.resume()
    return downloadTask
  }

  func urlSession(_ session: URLSession, downloadTask: URLSessionDownloadTask, didWriteData bytesWritten: Int64, totalBytesWritten: Int64, totalBytesExpectedToWrite: Int64) {
    //find the download task and updqate the progress
    let progress = Double(totalBytesWritten) / Doub    (totalBytesExpectedToWrite)
    let download = downloads[downloadTask.taskIdentifier]
    download?.setProgress(progress)
  }

  func urlSession(_ session: URLSession, downloadTask: URLSessionDownloadTask, didFinishDownloadingTo location: URL) {
    //find the download task and finish it with success
    let download = downloads[downloadTask.taskIdentifier]
    let destLocation = try! moveToDownloads(fileURL: location)
    download?.finish(url: destLocation)
    downloads.removeValue(forKey: downloadTask.taskIdentifier)
  }

  func urlSession(_ session: URLSession, task: URLSessionTask, didCompleteWithError error: Error?) {
    //find the download task and finish it with failure
    let download = downloads[task.taskIdentifier]
    download?.finish(error: error)
    downloads.removeValue(forKey: task.taskIdentifier)
  }
}

And here is an example of its usage

func downloadSomething() {
  let downloadTask = fileDownloader.download(from: somethingURL)
  Task {
    for try await progress in downloadTask.progressPublisher {
      //here you have the download progress
    }
  }
  Task {
    let downloadedURL = try await downloadTask.result()
    //here you have the download result
  }
}

But weâ€™re not finished yet! I will explain the rest of it in the two upcoming articles. In the next article I will explain how we can cancel and resume downloads. If youâ€™re bored with all of this implementation details and want to instantly jump and take a look at the final code, Iâ€™ve uploaded it on Gist.

Thank you for reading,

Cheers!

entry.content:
So here is the first post of this blog. Over the past few years I have had the opportunity to learn programming on my own which has led to woking in multiple startups and a big company. Well, I was quite busy with work all these times. Except doing some hobbies which were necessary to prevent burnouts I havenâ€™t done much else. During these times Iâ€™ve came across good blogs, RSS feeds and good dev communities. They have not only helped me learn and solve the problems I encounter at work and in my personal projects, but have also showed me how much developers are eager to share knowledge and collaborate with each other.

Additionally I realized there is a second group of developers to which I belong. The silent developers. We donâ€™t share anything, donâ€™t contribute to any open-source projects and donâ€™t answer any stack-overflow questions. Honestly there is nothing wrong about it. People are generally too busy with their daily life and knowledge sharing is usually time consuming. However, day by day as I spend more time in this field I come across interesting topics and ideas that I believe are worth sharing with other people.

I am aware of the fact that Iâ€™m probably not a good teacher or mentor. I donâ€™t have much experience in software development (4 years?). Iâ€™m not even good at writing things and also english is not my first language. I donâ€™t aim to create a well design and continuously updated tech blog, I simply need a place to comfortably write about interesting technical topics occasionally. I will write about some of the things that Iâ€™ve crafted and built over the past years, mostly based on Swift and iOS development. Additionally I may write about my personal thoughts and opinions about technical topics.
